published.fact_text: On 12 February 2001, NASA's NEAR Shoemaker probe performed an unplanned soft landing on the asteroid 433 Eros, becoming the first spacecraft to touch down on an asteroid. Engineers kept talking to the spacecraft for weeks after it "died", squeezing out bonus science from a vehicle never meant to land at all.

Many pieces were still warm when local people reached the crater field, a fresh scar where space quite literally hit Earth.

published.fact_text: On 12 February 1832, Ecuador formally annexed the remote Galápagos Islands—volcanic outcrops teeming with strange iguanas, giant tortoises, and finches that would later inspire Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution. At the time, no one imagined these rocky shores would become a living laboratory for how life diversifies.

published.fact_text: On 12 February 1817, an Argentine–Chilean army hauled cannons and men over the high Andes before defeating royalist forces at the Battle of Chacabuco. This improbable crossing—through thin air, snow, and sheer rock—became a symbol of the physical and mental endurance behind South America’s independence movements.

published.fact_text: In 1912, Puyi—the Xuantong Emperor and last ruler of imperial China—abdicated at just six years old, ending over two thousand years of dynastic rule. For a while he kept living in the Forbidden City as a ‘retired’ emperor, a child walking through empty throne rooms of a vanished world.

episode.title: Morning Drops #43 - Looking Back
episode.description:
In this first Morning Drop of 2026, Yasmin opens a space for quiet reflection on the nature of transitions. The episode traces a personal journey that began three years ago, when a sudden injury on New Year’s Day turned a desire for movement into a mandatory season of stillness.

Through the story of a broken knee and the slow process of relearning to walk, the narrative explores the difference between being strong and being aware. It touches on the vulnerability of the body, the unexpected joy found in daily progress, and the warmth that comes from finally allowing oneself to accept help. The musical selection mirrors this path of recovery, moving from the uncertainty of change to the steady rhythm of healing.

Mood: Reflective, Resilient, Grounded
Music genre: Indie Pop, Cinematic, World, Soul

We invite you to listen deeply and find comfort in your own pace.
songs: Kelly Finnigan - I Don't Wanna Wait
Goran Bregović & Iggy Pop - This Is a Film

published.fact_text: On this day in 1889, Antonín Dvořák’s pastoral-comic opera "The Jacobin" premiered at the National Theater in Prague. Beneath its lighthearted village scenes, the work quietly celebrates Czech identity and language at a time when music was a subtle tool of cultural resistance.

His brutal treatment stirred public outrage, influenced President Truman’s push to desegregate the military, and even echoed into cinema through works like Orson Welles’ "Touch of Evil."

published.fact_text: In 1404, the physician Galeazzo di Santa Sofia performed the first known post-mortem autopsy for teaching purposes in Vienna’s Heiligen–Geist hospital. At a time when cutting open bodies was controversial or even banned, this quiet dissection carved a path for modern anatomy and medical science.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1968, dozens of Vietnamese villagers were killed in the Phong Nhị and Phong Nhất massacre, reportedly by South Korean marines allied with the U.S. The incident remained largely suppressed for years, a grim reminder of how civilian suffering in war can be hidden in the margins of history.

episode.title: Morning Drops #44 - Residente
episode.description:
In this edition of Morning Drops, Yasmin navigates the complex geography of René Pérez Joglar, known to the world as Residente. His story is not just a musical evolution; it is a timeline marked by resistance, lyrical obsession, and a relentless search for identity.

From the gated streets of Trujillo Alto to the global stage, we explore how a restless mind transformed into the voice of a generation. The selection moves through the textures of his life: hearing the raw energy of his early rebellion, the sharp precision of his political critique, and finally, the fragile silence of his most personal confessions.

It is a study in duality. We witness the rapper who dismantles giants and the son who misses his mother. It is a soundscape that proves that sometimes, the loudest revolution happens inside.

Mood: Raw, Revolutionary, Introspective, Honest
Music genre: Latin Alternative, Hip Hop, Urban, World
